awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Collaborative Research: Optimizing Log-Structured-Merge-Based Big Data Management Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
Modern big data management systems support fast read and write operations based on the unique identifier (key) of a record. That is, they are fast when inserting key-value pairs, and given a key they quickly return the value associated with that key. To do so, most such systems rely on a Log-Structured-Merge Tree (LSM) structure that batches writes together before writing them to persistent storage. This project will study how to efficiently support more sophisticated operations on LSM-based storage systems, that is, operations that do not simply specify the key of a record. Examples of such operations include searching for records based instead on their location or time. By optimizing the storage and management of big data, this project has the potential to cut the storage costs and energy consumption in data centers. Further, the successful completion of this work will allow users to manage more data with the existing hardware infrastructure, which is critical given the new wave of big data being generated by sensors and the Internet-of-Things.  The project will capitalize on the student diversity at two Hispanic Serving Institutions, and thus broaden the participation of under-represented groups in the research process.

To support richer data modeling and querying capabilities on top of LSM key-value stores, this project will develop novel LSM indexing and access algorithms to support query plans that utilize both primary and secondary LSM components. In addition, it will design and evaluate flow control policies to dampen or eliminate the notoriously bursty data ingestion behavior that LSM-based storage structures exhibit. It will also study how to automatically and dynamically change LSM compaction policies and parameters based on the query workload. Data-semantics-aware compaction techniques will also be studied. The project will additionally develop novel LSM-aware query optimization techniques; the LSM storage layer is currently treated as a black box by most query optimizers. The planned methods will be deployed and evaluated on the open source Apache AsterixDB system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Most NoSQL or NewSQL database systems today rely on Log-Structured-Merge Tree (LSM) storage architectures that facilitate high write throughput as compared to older update-in-place architectures. Early systems supported only basic key/value read and write operations. Over time, richer data modeling and querying functionalities are being added on top of LSM storage systems. This new generation of Big Data management systems, LSM-BDMSs, leads to new fundamental research questions. The goal of this project has been to seek new foundational knowledge to significantly improve the performance of LSM-BDMSs. Work has been done by a multi-campus team from UC Irvine (UCI) and UC Riverside (UCR) on the following aims: (1) Perform holistic LSM indexing to optimize ingestion, access, and lifecycle management; (2) Create semantics-aware compaction strategies, including strategies focused on spatio-temporal data; (3) Expose and exploit information from the LSM storage layer to the query optimizer. The UCI side of the project has focused primarily on topic (1) and portions of topic (2). The proposed methods have been empirically evaluated in the context of the code base of the NSF-funded AsterixDB project, and the most promising results have been made available for use by the CISE community and the general public via releases of the open source Apache AsterixDB system.


Most LSM-related research has studied LSM storage only for key-value stores. LSM-BDMSs support much richer queries and data models than keys and values, including analytical queries requiring support for indexing, joins, grouped aggregation, and other related functionality. The UCI arm of this project developed novel LSM indexing and access paths to support query plans that access both secondary and primary LSM components. In addition, UCI designed and evaluated ingestion flow control policies to address the notoriously bursty data ingestion behavior that LSM-based storage structures can exhibit. UCI  also studied how to automatically adjust LSM compaction policies and memory-related parameters in the face of multi-query workloads. Also of major significance, the UCI arm of the project developed a new scheme for columnar LSM-based document storage, a scheme that provides  significant savings in space and much faster analytical query execution for complex queries. These results have been incorporated in the most recent Apache AsterixDB release. An approach to code-generating portions of query plans for even faster execution of queries has also been developed and prototyped, and it is a likely candidate for future inclusion in Apache AsterixDB. More details are available in the project's annual reports and in its conference and journal publications.


By optimizing the storage and management of Big Data, especially data that arrives at high velocity, the results of this project provide a means to cut the storage costs and energy consumption in data centers, both for "on-prem" and in the cloud settings. The results from this work should enable users to manage and query more data with their existing infrastructures. Key results from this work have been disseminated via the Apache Software Foundation and they have seen industrial uptake at Couchbase, Inc., in the Couchbase Analytics Service as well as a forthcoming Capella Columnar DBaaS offering. Work on this project has also provided an invaluable training opportunity for students involved, with project alumni now working at leading Big Data vendors and teaching the next generation of Big Data students in academia.
